Graphical abstract Atomically precise Ag30Pd4 nanoclusters exhibit strong adsorption and catalytic activity toward lithium polysulfides, providing the reaction mechanisitic insights for dynamic transformations. The separator modified by Ag30Pd4/rGO composite can effectively suppress the shuttle effect and significantly improve the cycle stability of lithium-sulfur batteries. Regulating the catalyst electronic structure is critical for improving the adsorption and catalytic conversion of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) in lithium-sulfur batteries (Li-S), yet which has been overlooked in current studies. In this work, structurally defined Ag30Pd4 nanoclusters were loaded onto reduced graphene oxide (Ag30Pd4/rGO) as a modification material for polypropylene (PP) separators to elucidate the catalytic activity towards lithium polysulfides and the impact on the electrochemical properties to lithium sulfur batteries. This unique d-π combination promotes charge transfer, influences overall charge states, and further enhances adsorption energies in potential reaction pathways with lithium polysulfides. Consequently, the Ag30Pd4/rGO/PP modified batteries exhibited an exceptionally low-capacity decay rate of 0.026% per cycle at 1.0C over 1000 stable cycles and 9.75 mAh cm−2 excellent performance even with lean electrolyte and high sulfur loading (9.7 mg cm−2). This study paves a path for employing ultrasmall bimetallic nanoclusters to promote the polysulfides redox kinetics hence boosting the lithium-sulfur battery performance. Keywords Ag30Pd4 nanocluster Separator modification Lithium polysulfides Adsorption Catalysis 1 Introduction Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have been widely regarded as promising candidates for next-generation energy systems due to the high energy density (2600 Wh kg−1) and low cost [1–3]. However, challenges such as poor conductivity of sulfur, lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) shuttling, and sluggish reaction kinetics significantly hinder their large-scale commercialization [4–6]. Improving the kinetics of LiPSs conversion through catalysis to accelerate LiPSs transformation and minimize LiPSs shuttling is an effective strategy to enhance the lithium-sulfur battery performance [7–10]. Nevertheless, the catalytic transformation of LiPSs involves a complex multiphase transition, closely related to the adsorption capacity and catalytic activity of the catalyst [11–14]. Rational control of the catalyst's electronic states to enhance its adsorption and catalytic capability is critical for regulating the redox behaviors of the active sulfur species. The catalysts with complex compositions may exhibit high catalytic activity, but it posesses challenges to comprehend the sulfur reaction pathway at the atomic level. Therefore, it is imperative to find an accurate atomic-level model to understand the origin of highly active catalysts, which is crucial for developing efficient catalysts for lithium-sulfur batteries. Transition metals with 3d orbitals are the most commonly used catalyst metals in electrocatalysis and photocatalysis systems [15–19]. The spin states of transition metal atoms can be modulated reasonably by coordination, magnetic field, or stress field [20–22]. These transition metal nanoclusters (MNCs) have unique advantages in the catalysis field due to their extremely small size, could expose more active sites on the surface [23,24]. Additionally, compared to relatively larger metal nanoparticles, metal nanoclusters usually exhibit different electronic structures, which can influence the catalytic activity and selectivity [25]. The electronic properties of metal nanoclusters are also strongly influenced by their size, which can be used to control catalytic reaction pathways and rates [26]. Furthermore, bimetallic nanoclusters typically exhibit excellent catalytic performance due to the alloying effect [27,28]. Introducing another metal can generate new catalytic active sites, and the formation of bimetallic-metal bonds can significantly alter the electronic structure of the catalyst. It is worth noting that, the redox reactions of sulfur in lithium-sulfur batteries involve multiple electron/proton transfer processes, producing various intermediates, which makes it challenging to elucidate the reaction mechanism unambiguously. Moreover, sulfur and polysulfides have very low electronic conductivity, resulting in slow reaction kinetics throughout the process. Therefore, in this study, the Ag30Pd4 bimetallic clusters with well-defined atomic structure was used as a catalyst model to explore its inherent activity in sulfur redox catalysis. Through the experimental and theoretical investigations, the impact of Ag30Pd4 cluster catalysts on various LiPSs and their reaction mechanisms were understood. Integrating the high activity of Ag30Pd4 with the high conductivity of rGO, the synthesized Ag30Pd4/rGO exhibits strong adsorption capacity and catalytic activity, enabling rapid reaction kinetics at high concentrations of polysulfides. Lithium-sulfur batteries equipped with separators modified with Ag30Pd4/rGO demonstrated high sulfur utilization, long-term cycling stability (over 1000 cycles with a low capacity decay of 0.029% per cycle at 1C), and excellent rate performance (921.5 mAh g−1 at 2C, 620.1 mAh g−1 at 5C), maintaining relatively good battery performance even under dilute electrolyte concentrations. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Preparation of Ag30Pd4 nanocluster and functionalized separator The synthetic process of [Ag30Pd4(C6H9)26](BPh4)2 nanoclusters (abbreviated as Ag30Pd4) and the preparation of functional composite materials for modifying separators are illustrated in Fig. 1 (a). The details regarding the synthetic procedure of Ag30Pd4 can be found in Supplementary material. Firstly, the precursor of (Ag-C≡C-tBu) n was synthesized according to the previous method [29]. Subsequently, the (Ag-C≡C-tBu) n precursor was added into a mixture of dichloromethane and acetonitrile in a certain volume ratio in an ice-water bath. Then, a specific amount of palladium acetate (Pd(CH3COO)2) was added into the above system. Subsequently, sodium cyanoborohydride (NaBH3(CN)) was slowly added for reduction. After workup of the mixture under light-protected conditions at 0 °C, NaBPh4 was added into the system as a counter ion. The pure dark green Ag30Pd4 solid was obtained through subsequent separation and purification. The Ag30Pd4 nanoclusters were loaded onto reduced graphene oxide (rGO) to form the composite material, which was then applied to modify commercial battery separators for use in lithium-sulfur batteries. Herein, the abundant layered two-dimensional planes of rGO served not only as the loading substrate for the nanoclusters but also as a multilayer physical barrier to impede the shuttle effect of LiPSs. The Ag30Pd4 clusters effectively adsorbed soluble LiPSs and catalyzed their rapid conversion to suppress the shuttle effect. Moreover, they improved the deposition mode of Li2S through atomic orbital overlapping, thereby effectively enhancing the redox reaction kinetics in lithium-sulfur batteries. 2.2 Microstructure characterization of Ag30Pd4/rGO composite By drop-casting a tetrahydrofuran solution of Ag30Pd4 onto rGO (Fig. 1a and Fig. S1), the Ag30Pd4/rGO composite were prepared. Their microstructural features are shown in Fig. 1(b–h). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) provides a clear view where uniformly dispersed metal nanoclusters on rGO were observed. As depicted in Fig. 1(b–d), the Ag30Pd4 clusters exhibit relatively uniform sizes (<3 nm) and are readily identifiable. Moreover, the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern also exhibites diffraction rings corresponding to the Ag and Pd crystal planes. Elemental mapping obtained via energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) demonstrates the uniform distribution of elements in the Ag30Pd4/rGO composite (Fig. 1e–h). Such uniform distribution of metal nanoclusters within the rGO layer ensures the exposure of abundant adsorption sites, facilitating the contact between the catalytically active sites and lithium polysulfides. The composition of Ag30Pd4 was confirmed and validated through mass spectrometry (Fig. S2a–b), absorption matching (Fig. S2c), and structural calculations. The composition and structure of the clusters are typically determined through single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD). However, since Ag and Pd are adjacent elements with nearly identical atomic radii and electron cloud densities, it is impossible to distinguish Ag and Pd using SCXRD. At this point, the composition of the clusters can be ascertained through high-resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS). Ag and Pd have completely different relative atomic masses, and varying the ratio of Ag-to-Pd will lead to differences in the positions of the corresponding mass spectrometry peaks. By analyzing the positions of the cluster's mass spectrometry peaks, the definite ratio of Ag-to-Pd can be obtained, which are shown in Fig. S2. Our analysis indicates that, when the ratio of Ag to Pd is 30:4, the isotopic fitting results are in good agreement with the experimental data, which further substantiates the composition of Ag30Pd4. Specifically, the alkyne ligands bind to the surface metal atoms via both σ and π bonding. The alkyne ligands exhibit strong interactions with both Ag and Pd atoms. Notably, Pd atoms tend to occupy the central positions within the cluster, resulting in the formation of a metal core with a flattened ellipsoidal shape. Additionally, four Pd atoms occupy the sub-centers of the cluster metal core and are surronunding by adjacent Ag atoms (Fig. S2d). This structural arrangement not only enhances the stability of the cluster but also facilitates bimetallic coordination for catalytic conversion of LiPSs. Various spectroscopic techniques were then employed to characterize Ag30Pd4 and the Ag30Pd4/rGO composite, revealing that the relevant data of the composite material remained unchanged before and after preparation, indicating the Ag30Pd4 nanocluster remain intact throughout the composite preparation. Using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), the charge states of Ag30Pd4 clusters were initially probed. As shown in Fig. 2 (a–c), characteristic peaks of the respective elements were observed in the full spectrum, with strong Ag and Pd signals in pure Ag30Pd4 clusters. Upon mixing with rGO, the C 1s peak (284.8 eV) and O 1s peak (532.9 eV) showed significant enhancement [30–32]. In the corresponding high-resolution XPS spectra, the electron binding energy of Ag 3d 5/2 in both Ag30Pd4 and Ag30Pd4/rGO was around 368.3 eV (Fig. 2b), indicating its charge state is (0, 1) but more close to the metallic state [33–37]. Additionally, the electron binding energy of Pd 3d 5/2 in Ag30Pd4 was 335.97 eV, consistent with Pd (0) [38,39]. The Pd peak in Ag30Pd4/rGO displayed a slight overall shift towards higher binding energies, likely due to the relatively low platinum content in the composite material (Fig. 2c) [40]. Hence, it can be confirmed that both the Pd atoms and most of the Ag atoms in Ag30Pd4 clusters are in a metallic state. Further insight into the structural characteristics of the Ag30Pd4/rGO composite was provided by X-ray diffraction (Fig. 2d) and Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 2e). The peak feature of Ag30Pd4/rGO is generally a combination of the Ag30Pd4 and rGO characteristic peaks, indicating the preserved crystal structure of Ag30Pd4/rGO but with some small changes in crystallinity due to the blending of the two materials. Together, these findings confirm the stability of Ag30Pd4 and rGO, with no change in chemical structure before and after the composite. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) testing was conducted to determine the pore structure of the composite. The results showed the presence of numerous micropores (<2 nm) and mesopores (2–15 nm) in Ag30Pd4/rGO (Fig. 2f). Typically, metal nanoclusters do not exhibit significant microporous structures, wherein small voids or gaps may exist but are insufficient to constitute true microporous structures [41]. The presence of microporous and hierarchical pore structures in this composite material is likely associated with the reduced graphene oxide, which offers a large surface area and layered structure suitable for adsorption and storage [42–44]. In lithium-sulfur batteries, the presence of such hierarchical pore structures can provide more catalytic active sites and adsorption sites, aiding in the adsorption and immobilization of LiPSs to mitigate the polysulfide shuttle effect. Microporous structures provide increased surface area and pore space, enhancing the contact area between the electrolyte and the composite material, facilitating easier penetration of the electrolyte molecules into the micropores. Additionally, the microporous structures offer more channels and interchannel gaps, providing additional diffusion pathways. Therefore, microporous structures are conducive to increase the diffusion rate of the electrolytes, thereby improving the battery's charging-discharging performance and cycling stability. 2.3 Theoretical calculation To elucidate the interaction between Ag30Pd4 and lithium polysulfides from both electronic and structural perspectives, we selected individual Ag30Pd4 nanoclusters as model systems and investigated the electronic structure and reaction mechanism of Ag30Pd4 with LiPSs. Fig. 3 (a) illustrates the charge density distribution of various chain lengths of LiPSs on the surface of Ag30Pd4 clusters, with corresponding molecular adsorption models shown in Fig. S3(a). Geometric optimizations of the adsorption systems revealed changes in charge density, with different adsorption systems exhibiting varying quantity of charge transfer (Q ct). The density function theory (DFT) calculation indicated that Ag30Pd4 gains electrons from LiPSs*, with charge accumulation towards Ag30Pd4, enhancing its affinity for Li+ in LiPSs. Additionally, the examination of LiPSs molecules revealed charge accumulation on certain S* atoms, which tend to react with free Li+ ions from the electrolyte to form shorter chain LiPSs*, thus facilitating subsequent transformations. Given the known reaction processes, we further computed the Gibbs free energy of lithium polysulfide conversion on Ag30Pd4. The adsorption of long-chain LiPSs* on Ag30Pd4 sites is thermodynamically downhill, demonstrating strong adsorption capability (Fig. 3b). Adsorbed Li2S8* gradually decomposes and releases out S*, which then reacts with Li+ from the electrolyte to generate short-chain Li2S x *. The adsorption capability of Ag30Pd4 for LiPSs increases gradually with the decreasing of molecular weight (Fig. 3c), likely due to more effective capture of smaller molecules. Effective adsorption of LiPSs by Ag30Pd4 facilitates their conversion during catalysis. The projected density of states (PDOS) of Ag30Pd4 (Fig. 3d) shows that the Ag/Pd orbitals in the cluster play a major role near the Fermi level, and the catalytic ability is affected by orbital interactions. Additionally, variations in charge distribution occur due to the presence of different types of Ag and Pd atoms, disrupting the uniform charge distribution on the metal surface (electron gain), allowing different atomic sites to interact and modulate the structure of electron clouds, thereby altering the catalytic activity. To further elucidate the binding interactions between Ag30Pd4 and Li2S, the PDOS near the Fermi energy for Li2S adsorbed on Ag30Pd4 is analyzed. The PDOS shows significant overlapping areas between Li2S and Ag30Pd4, indicating orbital hybridization. Specifically, p-d orbital interactions are observed between S and Ag/Pd atoms upon Li2S adsorption, while s-p orbital interactions occur between Li and Ag/Pd. The p and d orbitals of Ag/Pd exhibit a noticeable downshift following the adsorption of Li2S, attributed to the orbital interactions between Li2S and Ag/Pd (Fig. 3e). Consequently, the positively charged Ag30Pd4 tends to adsorb the negatively charged lithium polysulfides more effectively. These simulation results also reveal the strong affinity of Ag30Pd4 for LiPSs, thereby enhancing the redox activity in the system. 2.4 Polysulfides adsorption and catalytic conversion To verify our theoretical predictions and evaluate the mutual effect between Ag30Pd4/rGO and LiPSs, UV-Vis absorption spectroscopy was used to investigate the adsorption ability of rGO and Ag30Pd4/rGO in a Li2S6 dilute solution. After 2.0 h of adsorption, the Li2S6 dilute solution containing the adsorbents almost became colorless (Fig. 4 a). The UV-Vis absorption spectra results showed that Ag30Pd4/rGO had a better adsorption effect on Li2S6 compared to rGO, demonstrating a strong interaction between Ag30Pd4 and Li2S6. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was used to characterize the Ag30Pd4/rGO composite material before and after immersion in Li2S6 solution, and further analyze the chemical interaction between LiPSs and Ag30Pd4. By comparison, the survey spectrum (Fig. 4b) after adsorption showed the presence of characteristic peaks for Li 1s and S 2p (Fig. 4c), indicating that some Li2S6 had been adsorbed onto Ag30Pd4/rGO. Additionally, the Pd 3d peaks after adsorption (Fig. 4d) exhibited a shift to lower binding energies. This shift is due to the electron transfer from the adsorbate, leading to an increase in electron density around Pd, which is consistent with the computational predictions. To observe the inhibitory effect of the Ag30Pd4/rGO modified separators on the shuttle effect of LiPSs, we conducted visual observations using in situ optical microscopy and H-type electrochemical permeation tests. During discharging, sulfur gradually transforms into colored lithium polysulfides, which can dissolve into the electrolyte and cause a noticeable color change that is easily detectable. In situ optical microscopy recorded the permeation of LiPSs during the entire discharging process (Video S1), clearly showing that the unmodified PP separator had poor barrier properties against LiPSs (Fig. 4e), with yellowish electrolyte gradually permeating through to the negative electrode side over prolonged discharging duration. Conversely, in battery assembled with Ag30Pd4/rGO-modified separators (Fig. 4f), only a small amount of yellowish electrolyte appeared on the negative electrode side. Additionally, H-type electrochemical permeation tests (Fig. S4) demonstrated that, compared to the PP separators, the Ag30Pd4/rGO-modified separators were more effective in inhibiting the permeation of LiPSs during prolonged exposure to high-concentration Li2S6 solutions. In summary, these findings confirm that the Ag30Pd4/rGO-modified separators are effective in mitigating the shuttle effect of LiPSs in practice, effectively blocking LiPSs on the cathode and preventing them from corroding the lithium metal foil through the separator. Furthermore, the d-π orbital coupling between Ag30Pd4 and rGO can effectively promote charge transfer [45], enhance the adsorption and conversion of sulfur and LiPSs on the clusters, thereby effectively suppress the shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides within the lithium-sulfur battery system (Fig. 5 a). The nucleation of Li2S significantly impacts sulfur utilization and battery kinetics [46–49]. Studying Li2S deposition is essential for improving battery performance and achieving high sulfur utilization [50]. In the Li2S precipitation tests, the Ag30Pd4/rGO electrode exhibits the highest Li2S nucleation capacity of 143.32 mAh g−1 (Fig. 5b), much higher than rGO (54.54 mAh g−1) (Fig. 5c), supporting Ag30Pd4 clusters have a great electrocatalytic activity. To decipher the various growth behaviors of Li2S, we conducted dimensionless diagnostic analysis of current-time curves obtained from Li2S nucleation measurements using Scharifker-Hills models (Fig. 5d) [51]. The designations 3DP and 3DI denote instantaneous (I) or progressive (P) nucleation of a three-dimensional (3D) hemispherical nucleus with growth controlled by ion diffusion [52,53]. Upon comparing the test data, the transition from rGO to Ag30Pd4/rGO resulted in a shift in the Li2S growth mode from a 3DP model to a 3DI model, underscoring the effectiveness of Ag30Pd4 in facilitating instantaneous nucleation and dense Li2S growth. To confirm the predicted electrocatalytic properties of the Ag30Pd4 catalysts, an equal amount of materials was deposited onto an electrode, and the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of symmetric batteries containing a Li2S6 electrolyte were recorded (Fig. 5e). During polarization, Li2S6 undergoes a reversible process of conversion from soluble long-chain LiPSs to short-chain LiPSs at the anodes and cathodes, respectively [54,55]. The electrode loaded with Ag30Pd4 not only showed obvious characteristic conversion peaks, but also exhibited the largest peak area and highest peak current response compared to the rGO and PP electrodes, indicating its superior capability in enhancing the redox kinetics of LiPSs. In the fabrication of full batteries, typically a pursuit of low electrolyte addition and high active loading (E/S) is desired to ensure high energy density [56]. However, under low electrolyte content, the conversion kinetics of LiPSs are poor, which is a critical factor that results in inferior lithium-sulfur batteries performance [57–59]. Relevant studies indicate that when increasing LiPSs concentration in the system, the deposition rate of Li2S decreases, leading to a significant cathode discharge polarization [60]. The presence of Ag30Pd4 clusters is beneficial for the conversion kinetics of LiPSs. By using the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) to observe the sulfur redox process, particularly during the nucleation of soluble lithium polysulfides into short-chain polysulfides (discharge) and the dissolution of Li2S (charge), by comparing the GITT data of Ag30Pd4/rGO (Fig. 5f) and rGO (Fig. 5g), it was found that, less activation voltage was required in the presence of Ag30Pd4. The polarization of the lithium metal anode during both charging and discharging is quite low, whereas the kinetic problem in lithium-sulfur batteries is mainly due to the sluggish kinetics of sulfur conversion from the cathode, especially during the nucleation stage of Li2S, where a high kinetic energy barrier exists [57,61]. The results show that, the presence of Ag30Pd4 promotes the reaction kinetics of Li2S nucleation and activation process. Based on the electrochemical performance of Li2S6 symmetric batteries, the enhanced exchange current density confirms the catalytic role of Ag30Pd4/rGO in promoting redox kinetics (Fig. 6 a). Exchange current density describes the electrode's ability to gain or lose electrons, reflecting the ease of reaction [62]. According to the fitting results, the Ag30Pd4/rGO electrode exhibits a higher exchange current density (0.77 mA cm−2) compared to the rGO electrode (0.71 mA cm−2), indicating improved redox kinetics. Compared to CV curves of the rGO-modified separators and pure PP separators (Fig. S5), the multicycle CV curve of Ag30Pd4/rGO/PP displays more stable cyclic characteristics (Fig. 6b). Furthermore, the corresponding Tafel plots (Fig. 6c) show that the Ag30Pd4/rGO/PP lithium-sulfur battery exhibits the smallest Tafel slope values during charging and discharging, confirming the stable catalysis of sulfur and polysulfide conversion by Ag30Pd4/rGO [63]. Through comparison of the cyclic voltammetric contour plots at different scan rates (0.1–0.5 mV s−1) (Fig. 6d), the Ag30Pd4/rGO/PP battery exhibits more distinct reduction peaks (Peak A, B) and an oxidation peak (Peak C). These peaks involve complex multiphase transformations among solid S8, liquid long-chain lithium polysulfides, and solid short-chain lithium polysulfides Li2S2/Li2S [7]. Notably, compared to other batteries, the Ag30Pd4/rGO/PP battery shows more stable redox peak currents, lower polarization potentials, smaller electrochemical impedance (Fig. S6a), and higher lithium ion migration rates (Fig. 6e). To gain deeper insights into the dynamic characteristics of the Ag30Pd4/rGO/PP battery, in situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy data were collected at different charging/discharging states (Fig. 6f). The analysis indicates that, sulfur is progressively activated and transformed during discharging, and the increasing viscosity due to continuous dissolution of lithium polysulfides into the electrolyte gradually reduces ion conductivity, ultimately slowing down the cathode kinetics. Conversely, during charging, the resistance does not increase significantly. Importantly, the Ag30Pd4/rGO/PP battery maintains relatively low impedance and high lithium ion conductivity throughout, which correlates with the rapid transformation of LiPSs. Combining in situ Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 6g–i) provides more accurate tracking of lithium polysulfide conversion states [64]. As shown in Fig. 6(h), characteristic peaks of Li2S8 appear at 158 and 212 cm−1 at the beginning of discharging [2,65]. Subsequently, Li2S8 converts into other soluble long-chain lithium polysulfides, with the characteristic peak gradually disappearing and new peaks (Li2S n , n = 4 ∼ 6) emerging (Fig. 6i) [66]. Towards the end of discharging, under the catalysis of Ag30Pd4/rGO, smooth conversion to Li2S is achieved [12]. By comparing with the in-situ Raman data of rGO/PP battery (Fig. S6b), it can be observed that the presence of Ag30Pd4 is more conducive to the conversion of lithium polysulfides. Under the same test conditions, the presence of Ag30Pd4 results in a faster conversion rate of lithium polysulfides and stronger signals of lithium polysulfides being detected. These results collectively demonstrate the excellent catalytic effect of Ag30Pd4/rGO in efficiently promoting lithium polysulfide reaction kinetics. 2.5 Electrochemical properties of Li-S batteries The electrochemical performance of the lithium-sulfur batteries was investigated to verify the influence of the Ag30Pd4/rGO on Li-S redox reactions. Fig. 7 shows the electrochemical properties of lithium-sulfur batteries. Fig. 7(a) presents the galvanostatic discharge-charge profiles with an areal-sulfur mass loading of 2.0 mg cm−2 at 0.5C. The batteries containing Ag30Pd4/rGO, delivered a higher capacity (1078.5 mAh g−1) than those with rGO and PP (904.1 and 752.3 mAh g−1, respectively). These results suggest that Ag30Pd4/rGO has higher catalytic activity. Moreover, the catalytic activity of the host materials during LiPS conversion was quantified using the ratio Q2/Q1, where Q1 and Q2 represent the capacities of the two discharge plateaus [67]. Considering the electron transfers involved in each process (Q1: S8 + 4Li+ + 4e− → 2Li2S4; Q2: 2Li2S4 + 12Li+ + 12e− → 8Li2S), the ideal capacity ratio should be Q2/Q1 = 3 [12,68]. However, in practical scenarios, Q2/Q1 ratios are generally lower than 3 due to the sluggish redox kinetics of LiPSs and the loss of active materials induced by the shuttle effect. Notably, the Ag30Pd4/rGO/PP battery exhibits the highest Q2/Q1 ratio of 2.73 (Fig. S7a), which is attributed to its accelerated redox kinetics and effective suppression of LiPSs. It also highlights the ability of Ag30Pd4/rGO to reduce the electrochemical reaction overpotential and facilitate multistep catalysis for sulfur species. The rate abilities of various separator batteries were also measured to compare the reaction kinetics for lithium-sulfur chemistry. The capacity at different rates decreased as rate increased. The rate capabilities of various batteries were also measured to compare their lithium-sulfur chemical reaction kinetics. As the rate increased, the capacity of the batteries continuously decreased (Fig. 7b), and the electrode polarization voltage exhibited varying degrees of change. The Ag30Pd4/rGO/PP separator demonstrates effective polarization reduction, even under high-rate testing, compared to the rGO/PP (Fig. S7b) and PP (Fig. S7c) batteries. The Ag30Pd4/rGO/PP batteries can maintain normal charging-discharging curves and lower polarization voltages (Fig. 7c). Long-term cycling stability with high capacity retention is crucial for the practical application of lithium-sulfur batteries, so we tested the long-cycling stability at different rates. After 1000 cycles at 1.0C, the Ag30Pd4/rGO lithium-sulfur battery maintained a discharge capacity of 763.5 mAh g−1, giving an average capacity decay rate of 0.029% per cycle (Fig. 7d). The Ag30Pd4/rGO/PP batteries achieved a high capacity retention, and the capacity retention was still above 80% as the cycle approached 700 cycles. The improvements in cycling stability are ascribed to the moderate binding of Ag30Pd4/rGO, with soluble LiPSs and the fast desorption of precipitates. In addition, benefitting from the favourable catalytic effect of Ag30Pd4/rGO, high initial areal capacities of 6.45 and 9.75 mAh cm−2 are attained with sulfur loadings of 5.6 and 9.7 mg cm−2 (Fig. 7e), respectively, and such capacity is actually achieved under a relatively low E/S (5 μL mg−1). After 100 cycles at 0.1C, the Ag30Pd4/rGO/PP batteries maintain capacity of 8.76 mAh cm−2 at a high sulfurl loading of 9.75 mg cm−2, which is higher than a commercial Li-ion battery (4 mAh cm−2). In terms of areal capacity and total capacity, our lithium-sulfur batteries with Ag30Pd4/rGO modified separators represent a substantial advance and thus achieves higher gravimetric energy density compared with recent reported top-performance batteries (Fig. 7f) [69–74]. In order to verify the practical application potential of the Ag30Pd4/rGO/PP modified separator in lithium-sulfur batteries, we finally assembled a small pouch cell with a high sulfur loading (Fig. 7g) and successfully used it to drive a small fan (Video S2) for a long time. 3 Conclusions In summary, we successfully prepared the Ag30Pd4/rGO composite by loading atomically precise Ag30Pd4 nanoclusters onto reduced graphene oxide and used it to modify polypropylene separators. Due to the structural advantages and high activity of Ag30Pd4, Ag30Pd4/rGO exhibits high adsorption capacity for polysulfides and rapid reaction kinetics for LiPSs catalytic redox reactions. Density functional theory calculations demonstrate that the high binding affinity and catalytic performance of Ag30Pd4/rGO stem from the unique electronic structure and abundant catalytic sites of the Ag30Pd4 clusters. Furthermore, lithium-sulfur batteries based on Ag30Pd4/rGO/PP modified separators display excellent electrochemical performance in terms of capacity, rate capability, and long-term cycling stability. This study highlights the great advantages of using ultrasmall bimetallic nanocluster to promote the polysulfides redox kinetics in Li-S batteries, and may stimulates more research efforts in this interesting yet fast booming field in future. coredata.dc:description: Regulating the catalyst electronic structure is critical for improving the adsorption and catalytic conversion of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) in lithium-sulfur batteries (Li-S), yet which has been overlooked in current studies. In this work, structurally defined Ag30Pd4 nanoclusters were loaded onto reduced graphene oxide (Ag30Pd4/rGO) as a modification material for polypropylene (PP) separators to elucidate the catalytic activity towards lithium polysulfides and the impact on the electrochemical properties to lithium sulfur batteries. This unique d-π combination promotes charge transfer, influences overall charge states, and further enhances adsorption energies in potential reaction pathways with lithium polysulfides. Consequently, the Ag30Pd4/rGO/PP modified batteries exhibited an exceptionally low-capacity decay rate of 0.026% per cycle at 1.0C over 1000 stable cycles and 9.75 mAh cm−2 excellent performance even with lean electrolyte and high sulfur loading (9.7 mg cm−2). This study paves a path for employing ultrasmall bimetallic nanoclusters to promote the polysulfides redox kinetics hence boosting the lithium-sulfur battery performance.

coredata.dc:title: Atomically precise Ag30Pd4 nanocluster as efficient polysulfides redox catalyst in Li-S batteries
